data.text:
https://variety.com/2022/film/news/bruc ... 235219017/

Statement from the family as follows:

To Bruce’s amazing supporters, as a family we wanted to share that our beloved Bruce has been experiencing some health issues and has recently been diagnosed with aphasia, which is impacting his cognitive abilities. As a result of this and with much consideration Bruce is stepping away from the career that has meant so much to him.

This is a really challenging time for our family and we are so appreciative of your continued love, compassion and support. We are moving through this as a strong family unit, and wanted to bring his fans in because we know how much he means to you, as you do to him.

As Bruce always says, “Live it up” and together we plan to do just that.

Love,

Emma, Demi, Rumer, Scout, Tallulah, Mabel, & Evelyn

Red Letter Media guys had a good discussion on this recently. A few weeks ago they really panned some of his latest films but then more recently it was discussed that he was in some sort of mental decline and trying to cash in as much as possible before hanging up the spurs. Mixed feelings about it: I can't blame the guy for wanting to make as much as possible before the end but then it's kind of putting a pretty sad end to an illustrious career. Though the RLM guys did note that nobody is going to care about the truly awful movies that were made while he is obviously in decline, they'll just talk about his great roles.

Still there's quite a sadness that he (or his family, which if they were wringing him out while he's mentally impaired but still able to "work" is a whole 'nuther issue) had to do it this way. Goodness knows he's made plenty of money but then everyone can fall victim to poor financial planning in life. If anything it should be a good reminder to all of us to keep shoveling money into the retirement accounts and live modestly. If for no other reason than none of us truly know when our last day at work will be. Perhaps Willis thought he had another decade or so and all this has hit him suddenly and unexpectedly.

Anyway back to the RLM guys I can see people being upset at them razzing a fallen star on hard times, especially now that we know he was sick. However, this is also the profession Willis is in, if you go in front of a camera for money you need to be ready for criticism. Those last movies are shamefully awful. I think the blame really belongs in the producers more than Willis, especially considering the state he was in. If anything I think the criticism of those films is even more poignant now that it's under the light of possible elder abuse.

Aphasia is like bronchitis; it's a description of symptoms, not a cause.

Aphasia means a limited ability to understand or produce speech, due to some failure in the brain (not the vocal cords or ears). It can come from a stroke, dementia, brain cancer, or a hard knock to the head. There are even reports of it being caused by COVID.

And many reviewers noted that he was in a lot of tight shots so variations in camera lighting weren't as noticeable when other actors weren't in scenes with him, and the body doubles used didn't really match his physique. Even before the recent run of throwaway movies he might have been getting greedy - he was replaced by Harrison Ford in Expendables 3 because he was offered $3 million for 4 days work and he demanded $4 million.

That said, it's very sad that he's suffering this illness, and over time I'm sure he will only be remembered for his successes, and these tail-end phone-it-in movies will be forgotten.

The LA Times has a longish article on Willis and his decline.

It sounds like it has been a while, and that his handler is the one who pushed him into all of those junk movies over the past few years.

Maxing his cut of the action, sadly.

According to those who have worked with the elder Willis on his recent films, the actor has been exhibiting signs of decline in recent years. In interviews with The Times this month, nearly two dozen people who were on set with the actor expressed concern about Willis’ well-being.

These individuals questioned whether the actor was fully aware of his surroundings on set, where he was often paid $2 million for two days of work, according to documents viewed by The Times. Filmmakers described heart-wrenching scenes as the beloved “Pulp Fiction” star grappled with his loss of mental acuity and an inability to remember his dialogue. An actor who traveled with Willis would feed the star his lines through an earpiece, known in the industry as an “earwig,” according to several sources. Most action scenes, particularly those that involved choreographed gunfire, were filmed using a body double as a substitute for Willis.

In one alleged incident two years ago on a Cincinnati set of the movie “Hard Kill,” Willis unexpectedly fired a gun loaded with a blank on the wrong cue, according to two people familiar with the incident who were not authorized to comment. No one was injured. The film’s producer disputed that the incident occurred, but the alleged discharge left actors and crew members shaken.
